title: 103_hr1911
content: CHAPTER 90--MISCELLANEOUS EMPLOYEE BENEFITS: This section introduces reimbursement for adoption expenses under Subpart G of part III of title 5, United States Code. Sec. 9001 outlines adoption benefits for employees, defining terms like 'agency' and 'adoption expenses' related to the adoption of a child. Employees may be reimbursed for adoption expenses such as placement fees, legal fees, counseling fees, medical expenses, foster-care charges, and transportation expenses. Regulations require reimbursement only after the adoption is finalized according to the jurisdiction's laws. Employees may be reimbursed for adoption expenses up to $2,000 if the child is under 18 years old, unmarried, and if similar benefits from other programs do not cover the full expenses. Both adopting parents must be employees to qualify for reimbursement. Employees eligible for reimbursement under this section can receive up to $4,000 in total adoption expenses if both adopting parents are employees. Guidelines for cooperation and payment details are included in the guidelines issued under subsection (g). The amount payable will be taken from the appropriation or fund used to pay the employee. Employees eligible for reimbursement under this section can receive up to $4,000 in total adoption expenses if both adopting parents are employees. Guidelines for cooperation and payment details are included in the regulations issued by the Office of Personnel Management. The reimbursement will be taken from the appropriation or fund used to pay the employee involved. The Office may provide assistance to agencies upon request to carry out this section. The text discusses the amendment of part III of title 5, United States Code, specifically regarding "SUBPART G--ANNUITIES, INSURANCE, AND MISCELLANEOUS BENEFITS" and the addition of a new item for "Miscellaneous Employee Benefits". It also mentions the applicability of section 9001 of title 5 to Postal Service employees and the effective date of these changes. The Act will be effective on October 1, 1993, applying to adoptions finalized on or after that date.
